nodes.bodyText: arg_min?
arg_min is more standard math terminology, but min_by is going to be easier to locate for someone who is not familiar with the terminology.  Ok, I guess I'll change to arg_min
in the future we'll just have an Iterable trait...

Speaking of which, we don't have a way to implement lazy iterators at the moment (as they require either lifetimes or reference counting), so for example, if we have  e.filter(..).all(..), then filter will iterate to the end of the collection even if all can terminate early.

I think it should be possible to do that, but I don't know enough about Rust to see the potential difficulties.
Each element should have a reference in exactly one iterator, so I imagine it should be possible to do that.
perhaps you should be able to obtain an iterator only from an immutable vector. this is a reasonable constraint.

We'll need to add a concept of mutable variables  for that, but this still does not address the lifetime issue.  The iterator can outlive the vector it was create from. Without reference counting or a borrow checker we cannot support this safely.
how about an iterator that actually consumes the vector?

That might work, but again this is a pretty big change to the language (we'd have to annotate functions to consume their arguments and enforce that they are not used afterwards). And then you don't always want to consume the argument.  Point is, you cannot easily retrofit a new ownership model in the language.  There is a lot of complexity in Rust that takes care of that.
if there is a stable sort, why not expose that one too?
We can also have vec_sort_by_stable.  Stable sort is less efficient though.

So you compare pointer values?
Isn't there a safe way to do this?
I wonder whether this will cause problems in a distributed settings. I think that we have an invariant so far that the ordering/hash/equality of values on different machines is the same.

Isn't there a safe way to do this?
Not if pointers can point to functions of different types, which is the case here, because even closures of the same type can differ in the type of their captured values.


I wonder whether this will cause problems in a distributed settings. I think that we have an invariant so far that the ordering/hash/equality of values on different machines is the same.

It's not a problem for closures, as closures cannot be sent across the network atm (we'd have to parse and compile DDlog code on the fly).  But this may be a problem, e.g., for interned values whose order will definitely change as you send them across the network. #663 would address this problem.
I guess we won't worry about moving closures between machines then.

alternatively, you can look at the priority of the enclosing context and decide whether you need parens.
It's always safe with parens.
